description:
i always look forward to going into this shop when i go to japan town. i always buy the harajuku mochi chocolat, a very popular selection. this time, it wasn't that satisfying to me, it's probably due to how the older i get, the more less interested i get in sweets, but i still find myself eating them when i have nothing to do. other than that, it's very chewy, and has plenty of chocolate inside, that's probably why it's not as satisfying to me anymore, but do buy this if you have a sweet tooth !

they didn't tax me either !! so i payed $27 for three boxes of the harajuku mochi chocolat, somewhat of a good price !!
author: Rachel V.

description:
Good Japanese stuffs store! A lot of snacks and Japanese cute things. For snacks, they have Japanese Mochi, chocolate, cookies, etc.
For stuffs, they have cup, card holders, pin, etc.

Should come to this store if you visit Japan Town at San Fransisco
author: Linda L.

description:
When I walked into this small store I was so excited to see so many of the delicious treats I had enjoyed in Japan 10 years ago. As I went to check out, I was going to ask if they had castella cake, because when I was in Nagasaki I loved it. Imagine my joy as I got to the register and right to the left of me was the exact cake I bought in Japan: Nagasaki green tea castella. I almost cried. 

This store was by far my favorite highlight of San Francisco and the prices are exactly what I would have expected! Now I am sadly back in Connecticut but I am enjoying my castella, mochi, and daifuku!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Eh, it was cute and I thought it would be good. We got chocolate mochi and green tea. It was definitely something I would never get again. They're $9 a box
author: Becky N.

description:
A great place to find gifts.

Nippon-Ya has a variety of omiyage from different regions of Japan. The presentations were too cute. I appreciate that each piece is individually wrapped, perfect for sharing. Their cookies are not overly sweet, light, and just melt in your mouth. They also offer mochi, cakes, chocolates, tea, wine, candy, gift sets, and accessories. If you're in the area and looking for a gift for loved ones, this is an excellent place to check out.
author: Kimberly J.

description:
I wandered in here because all those boxes caught my eye. They sell all sorts of mochi. Cutely wrapped and packaged. I bought a box of sesame mochi for my folks.  I picked up a box of butter cookies with chocolate filling.  The butter cookies are crisp and tastes like butter!  

Items are reasonably priced for Japanese imported desserts. They pack a lot of inventory in this small store. 

Service is friendly. They also let you browse without doing a hard sell.
author: Wendy H.

description:
Years ago the place was super crowded so I would never go there. I made the effort to shop there 2 years ago and bought various sweets from them to try out.

It's small store which is rectangular in shape. Their sweets are on top of tall shelves and 3-level tables displaying their goodies. I've tried their sugar candies to eat and added to my coffee as a substitute for sugar. It had its own flavor of sweetness compared to sugar cane.

I was there for the Cherry Blossom Festival but mainly to shop around. I bought their Harajuku Mochi Chocolate.  The Cherry Blossom flavor one was sold out. 

The Harajuku Mochi Chocolates were encased in a nice flattering box to show how trendy it is. Opening the box, I see the lines of mochi all dusted w/ chocolate powder.  I tasted it and the mochi was delicious. I'll eat this with coffee next time.  If I'm in Japantown again, I will buy another box and see if they have something new.
author: Miriam T.

description:
Oh my gosh, this is SUCH a little gem in Japantown!  They have a wide selection of sweets and treats from Japan that are scrump-dilly-umptious.  I bought freeze dried strawberries covered in white chocolate that my family loved!  They also have a bunch of cute Hello Kitty SF Japantown merchandise which make great omiyage!

The service was exceptional.  I recently legally changed my last name, and the employees were very understanding about it and kind when they asked to see my ID with payment.  I am definitely coming back here soon!
author: Megan F.

description:
Nippon Ya is my not-so-secret gateway to squishy mochi and other Japanese sweets and  treats! Many items are imported straight from Japan, and I can confirm this after my recent visit a few months ago. I was pleasantly surprised to find the same boxes of mochi that I saw at Tokyo station for only a few dollars more here! 

The store carries mochi filled with more traditional fillings like red bean, but most of their mochi contain white or dark chocolate or even jams with cream inside. The colorful boxes of mochi keep for about 3 months and are great for gifts. These mochi are not to be confused with the larger fresh mochi at Benkyodo that are filled with fruits, lima bean paste, etc.

Other fun items to pick up are the bunny-shaped bean paste manju, Japanese flavored kit kats, and freeze dried strawberries coated in white chocolate. They have a variety of keychains and trinkets near the check out line and they can wrap your gifts in beautiful furoshiki wrapping cloth for a couple dollars more. 

I also always buy a 40g tin of ceremonial grade uji matcha powder when I'm here for $12.50, which is a fantastic price. 

Just keep in mind that everything is packaged here, but this can be a good thing if you're not planning on eating your treats right away or want to gift them. Japanese sweets don't contain preservatives though, so don't wait too long...but that shouldn't be a problem! Prices are pretty reasonable and their items are a great introduction to mochi if you're unfamiliar with them. Nippin Ya is a must-visit store for me in Japantown!
author: Deanna Y.

description:
Woaaaa this is definitely a gem in Japantown. Their mochi is so good, match and chocolate would be my favorite. It comes in very nice and minimal packaging so it is perfect for gifts. 
They also have variety of teas and fresh soba noodles. Yum!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
All the fresh mochi places are closed in the area, sadly.  So I googled it up and found that this place is highly recommended.  Nevertheless to say I was so happy to find this place.  The choice selections of Japanese desserts here were amazing. You can't find stuff here anywhere else or at least where I came from  (Seattle).  
I ended up buying myself chocolate matcha green tea mochi in the fancy box, chocolate mochi and these bunny shape dessert that was recommended by the store worker.  There were also tons of unique kit kat flavors.  
Idk, if you get a chance to be in the area, I recommend to check this place out and you won't be disappointed.  The prices are also reasonable!
author: Pawares P.

description:
Omg Omg Omg! Ahhhhh favorite little place in Japantown! Sooooo mad that I didn't buy anything because of analysis paralysis!!!

From floor to ceiling: mochi, chocolate, biscuits, candy - name the Japanese sweet indulgence and they FOSHO have it. There's stuff that I had never even seen before despite me going to Asian specialty stores almost weekly back home in Dallas.

The best part is that if you need a quick place to grab a nice hostess gift or little treat for someone special - no wait screw them buy something for youself - everything is packed in nice little packaging and gift boxes. :)

My fave finds: matcha dark chocolate truffles and taro mochi!!!
author: Anita N.

description:
The short: Ultimate place for Japanese sweets

Ever craving some Japanese snacks, candies, and desserts? This place will probably be your number one stop for all those sweet tooths out there. I have never seen so many different mochi, kit kat flavors, tea, and a lot of other unknowns that I'm sure will taste really good! And all of the stuff is beautifully packaged, so the treats make great gifts for people ;)
author: Catherine W.

description:
SO. MUCH. MOCHI. I'm talking peanut, black sesame, (real fragrant) red bean, mango, green tea, chesnut, and so much more.... sometimes rolled in the usual mochi powder, sometimes in cocoa, sometimes with sesame seeds, sometimes with matcha....the combinations are  seriously endless! 

And then there's the GORGEOUS packaging. Looking at the colorfulness and care in individual wrapping of a lot of the boxes here, you would never guess they were ~$10 or even under sometimes (have you seen the bunny shaped white bean manju? SUCH A STEAL FOR A CUTE GIFT!!).

If mochi isn't your thing, fear not, there's plenty of other sweets! Unheard of flavors of Kit-kat (roasted tea? HELLZ YEA!), French wafer/roll cookies, jelly based confections, star candy....Not big on the sugar? There's also hella fresh noodles, super cute knick knacks...I think I even saw some plushies on the side...

I'm such a hyper squirrel everything I go here..everything gets me super excited! LOL If you are in Japantown, make sure you swing by and check this place out!
author: Yen D.

description:
This place is definitely my spot for fancy Japanese boxed dessert needs! 

If you buy enough of their boxed desserts, they will give you a discount on your parking ticket at the Japantown parking garage. Be sure to ask!!!!!!!!

They have free samples of their popular mochis near their cash register!

They also have a display in the front of the store displaying all their popular mochi products. Super helpful for those who don't know what's good and for those, like myself who wants to try something new!
author: Alice X.

description:
Nippon ya... Nippon ya... You've made a convert out of me. Not a person who likes Mochi but your Harajuku Mochi chocolates got my vote. Who would think luscious chocolate with coffee would be a great Mochi flavored delicacy? It was a rare treat to the mouth as I savored you. I didn't know if I needed to bite the soft Mochi that encased this treat. It was a luxury in the palate. And for 9 bucks a box it was reasonable after the first taste.

Same for the strawberry chocolate. Think how they freeze dried each strawberry and then dipped into creamy white chocolate. It was science in your mouth and an adventure to your taste buds. The strawberry is like crunchy and dense with the tart of the fruit still present but the chocolate neutralizes that's tartness and so it was a gastronomic experience.

Sadly these arE just two of the items I sampled and they have more in this quaint store. I will be back for sure and will try other stuff.
author: Joy U.

description:
They sell traditional mochi, chocolate mochi, unique flavored kit kats, and other snacks from various parts of Japan. Plus they have a star wars corner and tea corner.

Currently there is bogo free with certain boxes so i got 3 boxes for only $20!! I haven't tried any yet since I'm giving them as gifts to my bfs family this weekend.

They accept credit cards.
author: Mimi T.

description: Great selection of traditional and modern mochi, with a friendly and respectful staff. I had a great experience here and it has legit mochi.
author: Carlos C.

description: so much different kinds of tea, mochis, cookies, AND KIT KAT.
author: S L.

description:
Small Japanese gift shop that houses many well-chosen Japanese treats, teas and gifts. At Nippon-Ya you will find luxury boxed Japanese chocolates, pretty packaged treats and gourmet teas. 

Indulge yourself --or that special person in your life--with Harajuku Mochi Chocolates, Cherry Blossom cookies, Green Tea Kit Kats or Chick-shaped steam buns filled with white bean. The Chick Steam Buns are so cute! I saw a lady filling her cart with these...they really do make a lovely gift. 

I walked out with a bag of matcha green tea and a box of the Harijuku Mochi Chocolates  The matcha green tea is very good --I really look forward to having a cup or two during the day. The Harijuku Mochi Chocolates were a nice treat. They are the perfect after-dinner treat accompanied with a little red wine. I'll have to buy these again when I come back. 

Make gift shopping easy or pick up  something special for yourself at Nippon-Ya. Very fun shop! Gonna make some tea now.
author: Nicole D.

description:
I'm a huge fan when it comes to Japanese sweets, and Nippon-ya has a great collection of Japanese-imported sweets. I always make it a stop to visit this small shop located in the Japantown mall whenever I'm in the area. While pricier than what you would find in Japan, it's not bad for what you can get in the states.

From unique KitKat flavors to delicious mochi desserts, there's pretty much always a way to alleviate your Japanese sweets cravings. They usually show the recommended items that are popular so definitely check those out!
author: Alvin W.

description: You really can't help but walk in to Nippon Ya when you see it at the Japan Center.  They have some very classy candy and snacks here.  They say in Japan that they're really serious about the packaging because they want all their products to be beautiful.  You're going to be so tempted to buy something and even though things are pricey, you're not going to care.  I bought myself a box of Harajuku Mochi Chocolates (http://bit.ly/1R9QhmO) because I just liked the box!  If you're looking for a great gift, I highly recommend coming here.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Cute little snacks and sweets store that specializes in goods from Japan. It's located on the west wing of the mall in Japantown and has an open store front so it's not easily missed. 

We came in hopes of finding hakata torimon but left with a box of red bean mochi infused with sake and a box of sweet white bean cakes.

- Red bean mochi: It's a box of 12, I believe. They were good but the texture wasn't exact to the soft, chewy texture of mochi. 
- Sweet bean cakes: I was hoping these would be similar to torimon and it was, but the texture of the filling was off. Torimon has a creamy filling while the filling for these are a bit crumbly. These came in a box of 16.

The store is divided into sections so it's easy to narrow down what you want. Although this store imports goods from Japan, my boyfriend didn't see one thing that he's had or seen from Japan. It's not a question of authenticity but it was interesting to hear that from him. 

The person working wasn't helpful one bit and didn't bother getting up from his seat to answer any questions or give any recommendations. There's a box of their most sold item as a sample but it was empty when we went. 

Attaching pictures of what we bought to gain a better sense of what was purchased.
author: Valerie D.

description:
Nippon Ya has all your Japanese snack and candy goodies straight from Japan!

This place brings back memories of traveling to Japan by the placement of the fake plastic snacks on display, the various flavors of kit kats available, and well, the Japanese snacks! On occasion, they even have free samples which are definitely a treat.
author: Joshua M.

description: Can't find Harajuku mochi anywhere else - wish I stocked up on the green tea and tried the strawberry before flying back home but my luggage restricted me with the limited space.
author: Joanne H.

description:
My son n I love the chocolate and strawberry harajuku mochi's from here. They're soft and chewy little bites of heaven! One box has 16 mochi's each one is a little bit bigger than a quarter.
$9 a box no tax...
author: Liz N.

description:
So what prompted me to visit Japantown was this picture of mochi shaped like bunnies from Nippon Ya. I love everything rabbit related and these mochis looked just too good to be true and well unfortunately they were. 

Nippon Ya carries a variety of Japanese treats from candy to mochi to various other gift items packaged in exquisite cute boxes. We picked up three flavors of the bunny mochi (green tea, coffee, and cherry). The display for the mochi looked absolutely adorable...white mochis with ears and eyes. Although when I opened a box I realized that it looked nothing like the display! You could hardly tell the mochi was a bunny :(. The markings were faded and it definitely wasn't cute at all. Hoping it would taste better than it looked I bought these back home and tasted all three flavors before gifting a couple to my friends. Sadly they were way too sweet and wasn't as good as I had imagined either. I haven't completely given up on Nippon Ya yet so I'll probably visit again during my next SF trip but I'll pass on the packaged bunny mochis and purchase freshly made ones instead.
author: Shanon Y.

description:
Nippon-ya is the perfect place to buy prepackaged Japanese snacks and sweets.  This charming little store is located inside Kintetsu Mall at Japantown.  In addition to sweets, the store also has a respectable inventory of green tea and green tea products.  If you're looking for a Japanese or confectionery gift (or heck, just a gift in general), look no further.

Like most Japanese stores, especially gift shops, Nippon-ya has a cute design.  In this case, pink paint, light woods, and cherry blossoms for decor.  Even though the store space is small, inventory is neatly packed and organized.  There are a bevy of products stacked high and everything is beautifully presented and displayed.  The packaging is colorful and adorable -- yes, girls and people into "kawaii" things will love this stuff.

Examples of nifty treats include:
* Usagi Cream Daifuku Green Tea - mochi with a green tea-flavored white bean filling and cream center (the mochi balls look like little bunny rabbits).
* Oideyasu Kyoto - shortbread cookies decorated with a chocolate image of the Kyoto temple.
* Miyazaki Mango Eclaire - cream puffs filled with custard and mango puree, covered in milk and white chocolate, and topped with freeze-dried mango.
* Mameta Tofu Crunch - rice puffs covered in white chocolate topped with black sesame seeds and freeze-dried tofu.

Harajuku Mochi Chocolat is sold here as are a lot of other chocolate products.  In addition, you can find cute keychains, lovable stuffed animals, and creative tea sets.  Take a look at my photos and you'll see what I'm talking about.  Most of the candies and gifts are under $10 per box or item.  It's worth it because this stuff is imported from Japan, unique, and high quality.

If you're traveling and packing your gifts away in luggage, Nippon-ya staff will nicely package your purchases to prevent damage.  They accept online orders and ship (domestic or worldwide, I'm not sure).  The staff is efficient and friendly.
author: Daniel B.

description:
OHHH MYYY OHHHMYYY! I can't believe I stumble upon a great shop for Harajuku Mochi Chocolat!! FYI: it's my first time seeing the product. I thought it was amazing and only brought two different kinds because it was kind of expensive.. :( I got the matcha green tea mochi with chocolate filling and chocolate mochi with strawberry filling. 

This Jtown located in S.F seems like they are the only one who sells this stuff besides Japan!! :( I came home from my S.F trip and decided to search this product online so I can buy more maybe at a cheaper price..but it all led me to this Yelp page!! :( 

They are so good. It's so soft and tastes so fresh! 

If anyone know where else I can buy this product besides this S.F location or Japan..Please let me know!!! :(
author: Amy L.

description: Very great place for delicious and beautifully decorated gifts. Most of the items aren't too expensive and the store has a wide, diverse selection of goods from hard candies to green tea to little cute figurines. I really recommend this place if you want to try small delicacies from Japan!
author: Leslie S.

description: Only place where you can get legit chocolate mochi that is not ice cream filled! I don't know why but it is extremely difficult to find this type of chocolate-filled mochi in LA. I assumed that Little Tokyo shops would have it but nope. Only thing close to it was Fugetsu-do's Nutella/chocolate mochi but subject to expire in a few days. But the Harajuku mochi boxes last longer and perfect for gifts or just to eat them all for yourself :o if I go back to SF, I'll definitely stop by this shop and stock up on these for sure!
author: Tay L.

description:
They have some really good candy that they sell here as well as mochi boxes. If you haven't tried mochi, they have free samples here too!

I love how it's brightly lit and organized. It's very colorful in here it kind of reminded me of Tasty Sugar except the colors weren't visually overwhelming.

Definitely would love to come back here! I recommend this place.
author: Aj C.

description:
This is my first stop whenever I head to Japantown. When you first set foot in it is visually pleasing, countless pretty packages of mochi and sweets are stacked upon each other. 

I like to buy blind here. I just pick a random package and hope for the best. It always goes well, even if it doesn't taste the best it still looks beautiful. My favorite was the black sesame mochi, and the cocoa dusted chocolate strawberry mochi. Not sure if it's still there, though.
author: Eulla S.

description:
Got back from Tokyo last month and couldn't find Harajuku mochi during our trip.  Well, it looks like I didn't have to fly that far because this small shop in SF's Japantown has all the pre-packaged mochi that you'll need! 

They have several Harajuku mochi flavors available -- chocolate, melon, strawberry, green tea.  The classic chocolate is and will always be my favorite!  Reasonable price too -- $9.99 for a 16-piece box.  They also have other treats, I just never get to them because the Harajuku mochi is in the way!
author: Dawne L.

description: Stopped in again and got some more manju and yup it didn't disappoint.  Will keep coming back to this place.   Can't go wrong with anything you buy.
author: Eric K.

description:
*Sigh*

I am a sucker for Japanese sweets, especially when the packaging is super cute and pretty; just love how the Japanese are very elaborate and delicate with their packaging - skills!  

Tucked in a back corner of SF Japantown mall, this store offers delicious small bites of mochi goodness.  My all time favorite is their sakura harajuku mochi with white chocolate filling...mmm yummy!
author: Veronica C.

description: I love this store! They have a lot of Mochi and others snacks here like cookies and tea. The boxes aren't really that expensive like $10-$20 per box for most of them, but the presentation is done really nicely on these boxes. The designs are very pretty. I'll probably come back for more if I need some last minute gift ideas (which is what happened).
author: Danielle C.

description: This has good sweets to give as presents/souvenirs. Especially their mochi, I think I bought quite a few of the flavors.
author: Melissa C.

description:
A great place to pick up some gifts. These lovely Japanese treats will certainly put a smile on your recipient's face. Nippon Ya sells regional souvenirs (mostly candies and other edibles) imported from Japan. Similar to those gift shops you found at Tokyo airport. The selection here is much better than most Japanese groceries in the area. 

Everything looks adorable and are surprisingly affordable. Mostly less than $10 a box. Good things do come in small packaging. I purchased some usagi manju and Japanese tea for Christmas white elephant and they were big hit among everyone. I bought some yuzu mochi and chocolate mousse candies for myself and they tasted great. 

Most of the stuff they sell are seasonal. They always have something different every time I visit. If you found something you like just grab it or you might not see them again until next year.
author: Mona W.

description:
I love San Diego, but in terms of culture and good Japanese food or good manju/mochi, San Diego is definitely lacking. Found Nippon Ya and was in manju/mochi HEAVEN!!!

Ended up buying various types of packages and was able to take it back on the place with me as a carry on (unopened.. I left it sealed to be on the safe side).
author: Jordan M.

description:
Amazing candy!  My wife always gets the mango drops when we are in Japan town. Some of the stuff is a bit pricy but that seems to be because you can't find a lot of these sweets anywhere else. 

Worth checking out, especially for birthday gifts and indulgences!
author: George A.

description:
This place is surrounded by beautiful boxes of mochi! I mean, how could I have missed this place all these years!?

I had bought a box of Harajuku mochi Sakura flavored and while the packaging and the inside were both beautiful and breath taking, they were not that good. On a scale of 1 - 10, it ranked a 6. Service here was alright. Not much interaction. Just scan, pay, and leave. You can go on to the Japantown website and print a 10% coupon for Nippon-Ya if you want to save a little cash. 

If you want yummy fresh mochi, I suggest you head over to Benkyodo across the street.
author: Venus L.

description: Honestly i don't love mochi all that much but I love coming here just to see what they have and also because they have an excellent selection of green tea and matcha related things.
author: Emelia W.

description:
Finally! Hehe, got myself a box of Harajuku Mochi Chocolat (the sakura one)! It has a delicate, sweet sakura flavored mochi with a sweet white chocolate filling. So soft, so sweet, and a bit powdery with starch, on the outside! It was sweeter than I remembered it, but still better than just any mochi I'd find at 99 Ranch market in a box... oh, no. Never again.

I have also had their sakura drops, which were also very delicately flavored with sakura. It mostly tasted like sugar, but I enjoyed them, and the tins are cute. To open the tin easier, though, you'd probably need to pry the lid with some keys or something. I remember them being difficult to open. I was going to buy another tin of hard candies, but didn't today :(

There are 16 pieces of mochi, by the way. They are a bit bigger than the size of a quarter, and the box was 9$ each :) I just ate 4 as I was writing this review. I need to get someone else to hide this box, because I keep digging it back out when I hide them on my own. I need to stop

The person working at the store was very kind. He went to the back of the store to grab the mochi I'd asked him to reserve for me (as I was afraid that flavor would be gone again) He took a look at the boxes and after a moment, went to replace 2 of them for some of the fresher boxes of mochi they had. So kind and thoughtful! Thank you! Of the three times I came here, they were always nice. I never fail to stop by this store when I visit Japan Town.
author: Michelle C.

description: Amazing place to find many different kinds of mochi... my new favorite one now is the harajuku chocolate mochi.  I can't wait for my next visit to Japan town in SF.
author: L D.

description:
If you focus on the pastel colored boxes, you almost (almost!) feel like you're in Tokyo. With mochi boxes and tea canisters lining the shelves, helpful store employees, and even yatsuhashi (super-crunchy cinnamon cookies which I can't find anywhere else), this store is my Tokyo-away-from-Tokyo.

After filling-up on some ramen or sushi in the area, stop by Nippon Ya for a box (or three) of mochi and head home to re-watch episodes of Densha Otoko.

If that isn't a Japanophile's dream, I don't know what is!
author: Adena B.

description:
Whenever I see this store, I'm overcome with glee -- seeing the fully-stocked walls of yummy deliciousness!   A sight for sore eyes for the beholder of an empty stomach.  There was such a huge selection.  Many different boxes and types to choose from.

I prefer Nippon Ya (over Minamoto) for my Japanese confections, since I have an affinity for mochi -- in a variety of flavors in beautifully-wrapped boxes.  They're ideal for gifting, like yourself (!).  I bought myself green tea mochi and mango.  You definitely get more bang for your buck, 30 mochi for $10?!  That's unthinkable in a shop like Minamoto, where one large one costs $3 each.
author: Melinda Y.

description:
Located inside the Japanese Center - West Mall, this is one of my favorite place to get mochi. They have such a wide variety to choose from. If you tell them what you're looking for, they can usually help you find something that fits your tastes.

I love black sesame mochi (one that has a really strong flavor) and they have two brands that really satisfies my palette. Lately, every-time I go, they're sold out though. :(

I used to get really fresh white tea here as well but due to FDA regulations, they could no longer sell them. Sadness. :(
author: Kitty K.

description:
A cute little store in the Japantown mall that I'd never noticed before. Probably because all of their food goodies are prepackaged for gift giving. However after a holiday in Japan and drooling over all those treats I was really happy to find them available more locally - and at such reasonable prices. This may not be top of the line but they have a nice variety of mochi from traditional to chocolate to puffed rice. The boxes range from $10-20 - about $1 / mochi. The emphasis here is really on mochi and less on the usual candies/crackers you get at the grocery store.

Definitely not as high end as Minamoto Kitchoan downtown but not everyone wants to spend $3 / treat.
author: Jean K.

description:
My go-to spot every year to get some Christmas gifts! :)

The mochi snacks here are all delicious, they also have different candies, cakes, crackers, and other goodies.  I just stopped by on Wednesday (Christmas Eve) and left with like 15 boxes, lol.
author: Marc B.

description:
FREE SAMPLES. By the cashier. If you go at the right time.

This shop utilizes its small square footage quite well. It's jam-packed with mounds of mochi, along with super expensive charms and plushies.

I ended up buying a box of CHOCOLATE STRAWBERRY MOCHI for my dad, $8 for 16  pieces. Funnily enough, I think my brother ate them all.

Chewy, not-too-sweet, and a good gift for friends and family :)
author: Adele F.

description:
This review is more about Karen, the person who helped me today. Finally, someone who was willing to help me wade through the wide selection of sweets.  Karen had lots of information to share about the products.

I am not too familiar with Japanese sweets. Every year I go to this store to buy treats to send in celebration of the new year.  The recipients are from Japan living in the United States.  The staff typically points me to the shelves with the top rated items.  Today, it was different.

With Karen's help, I actually went over budget. But, I am confident there will be some pretty happy people come January 1st.

I have also sent a commendation for Karen to corporate.
author: Debbie T.

description: A friend gave me a box of the New Summer Orange Mochi.  It was beautifully wrapped.  On opening the box, I immediately ate 4 pieces - I couldn't eat just one!  Then I hid the box.  Is that mean?  They are sooo good and I don't know how or when I am going to get another box.  I have to find out if they ship items!
author: Tricia K.

description: I always come here and spend around 50 bucks grabbing mochi boxes and tea when I visit SF.  They have the best goodies that you can't buy in an asian supermarket back in the East coast.  Too bad we don't have this in DC...although NYC probably has something similar.
author: Tim K.

description:
You know how sometimes you're starving, like absolutely ravenous, so just about anything and everything sounds absolutely amazing?  Yeah, when that happens, avoid this place.

Maybe I'm just missing something since most other Yelpers seem to love it.  Sure, the service was super sweet and friendly, but that did not make up for the mediocre mochi.  I usually walk right on by this place - have done so for years and years - but this time, hunger made me take a pause and whip out about $15 for two green tea varieties.  D and I ended up trying one of each, and we were not impressed at all.  The mochi were not soft or chewy as fresh mochi is.  I actually ended up tossing the boxes after they just sat on our kitchen counter, undesirable and untouched, for weeks.

I think part of the issue is that I'm used to fresh mochi.  And boxed Nippon Ya compared to the real thing?  Why even bother?
author: Mel T.

description: My goodness, I felt like I was at a rest stop in Japan. All the treats from all parts of Japan. The prices were very fair plus they gave you a free gift for spending $50. And the gentleman behind the counter was such a good salesman! I probably ended up spending $30 more than I planned on because of his pitches!  They have samples for you to try too! Great gift and souvenir items here!! Pastries and chocolates for kids and teas for adults!
author: CJ B.

description: I love this place. Love the sesame mochi and the strawberry chocolates! They make nice gifts.
author: Doris U.

description:
I stumbled into this Japanese style confections and gift shop by accident and it was a good thing because they had so many items that reminded me of Japan. They had a huge assortment of candies, biscuits and sweets that are imported and beautifully boxed. These are the kind of gifts you would want to gift as a omiyage (bring home gift) to friends and family. I'm glad I picked up the strawberry mochi ($7.50ish) because my guest back home really enjoyed it. 

One noticeable thing you must be aware here is some of the food items have short expiration dates. I had to put back a few goodies because a few were going to expire in a few weeks. For example, if you see "09.7.12." that means it will expire July 12, 2009 not December 7, 2009. Year, month, day. Always make sure you look at that before you make your purchase. 

While trying to remember the name of this shop, I found a printable coupon you can use for 10% off. 
http://japantownparking.com/Business/index.cfm?bizID=41&popup=1

Aahhhh, finally finished with all my San Francisco reviews! Now moving onto the South Bay!
author: Santi T.

description:
This place is like the Japanese See's Candy shop!  But Mochi style.

So, I popped a sample chocolate mochi into my mouth...  I closed my eyes and chewed in slow motion.  It tasted like a cloud floating inside my mouth.  It was so soft, it was lightly sweetened, it was chocolate flavored and it made me feel happy inside.  I swear I started floating up and my twinkle toes started dancing in mid-air.  

Wowz!!  MAMA!!  It was amazing!  Needless to say, I threw down my $9 for a box to bring home.  Fresh, fantastic and fun-derful!
author: Jenny T.

description:
Everything here is so cute, presentable, artsy-fartsy, delicious and expensive.  But really what do you expect from Japanese sweets?

This shop has plenty of perfect gift ideas to bring back home from Japantown.  They have a good variety of products such as mochis, chocolates, cookies, and biscuits.  The one that I actually bought is the Rainbow chocolate pigs.  $9 for 8 pieces.  Expensive but worth it because it was so cute.

Definitely worth looking at when you're at Japantown.
author: Jackie N.

description:
Nippon ya sells candies, teas, cookies, nuts, edibles, chocolates, many coming from japan. nippon ya is an hole in the wall in Kintetsu Mall. the goodies are neatly and artfully displayed thruout the small shop.

sampling: harajuku mochi chocolat (12 pieces in colorful box. 8.75 no tax)
-melt in your mouth chocolat flavored mochi with strawberry center
-many varietals available, no mixed ones, all single varietals.

temaki:
-friendly, helpful, courteous service
-items are classily packaged, idea on special occasions as gifts.
author: Victor G.

description:
I love this store. It's a cute little hole in the wall stuffed with many boxes of mochi and other delicious things. Don't worry if you can't read the Japanese on some of the boxes. Everything has a sign that says what exactly is in them and what flavors as well as the price. And if you look on the back of the boxes they have the ingredients on the back in English as well as the nutritional value. All the boxes are beautifully wrapped and packaged you don't even want to open them!

They have all the mochi flavors that I like with -reasonable prices-. The Harajuku Chocolate Mochi in the black box comes 16 in a box and the Sesame Mochi Hinokuniya with black bean paste comes 12 in a box. They have various traditional hard candies like konpeito and temari. They have nuts, white chocolate covered freeze-dried strawberries that remind me of malted milk balls, cookies, random little gifts like stuffed animals, keychains, and cute wooden figurines.

I got those two boxes of mochi, two little packages of konpeito, and a package of the white chocolate covered strawberries for around $25.00.
author: Venus L.

description:
I really like this little shop in J-Town. It's just the perfect place to pick up a small snack or to pick up some gifts for friends. It's a cute little snack store with some random knickknacks against the wall. 

They are always super friendly here AND there's always a sample of some kinda mochi at the register. I've tried a few different ones and they are all pretty delicious. I haven't tried anything else besides the mochi but if it's along the same lines of quality, I'm sure those other snacks are delicious as well.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
Let me begin by saying,  I LOVE mochi, and have definitely tried to go out of my way to find authentic and scrumptious mochi in the bay area. Although Benkyodo remains dear and true to my heart, the prepackaged and imported mochi sold at Nippon-ya are also impressive. Don't expect mochi to taste fresh/home-made quality (if you're looking for that, walk two blocks away to Benkyodo), but do expect to get some beautiful, moist and dreamy confections imported from Japan. In contrast to packaged mochi from other places, the ones here neither taste like plastic or are overly sweet.

I would say the prices are reasonably, ranging around $9-12 per box, for 9-12 mochi. So that would be around $1 per mochi. They have boxes offering your standard azuki (red bean paste) mochi, but I'd recommend going for something unique. Since having been introduced to their mochi I have enjoyed and recommend the following:

-strawberry chocolate mochi
-mango daifuku
-bunny cream mochi collection
-green tea white chocolate mochi

I think their offering changes occasionally, depending on their stock availability, However, it's always a treat when I purchase a new box of mochi there. I believe anyone who is a fan of asian confections should drop by if in the area.
author: Jenny Z.

description:
The last time I was in Japan, the whole experience was pretty damn awesome.  Checking out the sites, eating plenty of good food, almost drinking too much free sake and plum wine at 9:00am at a sake factory...loads of fun!  Probably the worst part of the trip though, was trying to get everything to fit in my luggage for the flight home.  Who knew that a few bags of tea leaves, snacks, and mochi could take up so much space?  So, imagine my simultaneous joy and dismay that in the middle of J-Town, there's a shop that sells almost the same type of stuff that I had to cram into my luggage.

From chocolates and candies, to assorted varieties of mochi, Nippon Ya is practically a one stop shop for so many different sorts of Japanese confections.  It's perfect for the tourists that roll on through to get an authentic taste of Japanese sweets while in SF.  But better yet, it's the perfect way to get your tasty treats home without having to cram them into your suitcase next to your dirty laundry (mmm....yum).  

Plus, it's perfect for when you realize you forgot to bring something back from Japan for that one friend who you know will bitch you out for not getting them a souvenir.  Or, for those of you that want to pretend that you've even been to Japan in the first place as well.  ;)
author: Mike L.

description:
I highly suggest this box with little packages of grape jelly and grape in it. And the chocolate chocolate mochi in the black box. 

Ask the folks at the counter for a sample. They had one kind out for people to try. 

There are great gifts for housewarmings, dinner parties or even birthday gifts.
author: Debbie N.

description: I love most anything Japanese.  This place is a dream come true. I adore Japanese sweets, the packaging is perfectly done. My usual place for these treats is downtown and very very expensive.  Everything is packaged and the box's are cute too. My advice is go when you have time to linger.  The shelves are packed with interesting products and I like to look at everything.  The staff was friendly and when they realized I wanted fresh made mochi they sent me a block away to the best little place. Going to yelp tomorrow on that..I picked out some Japanese crackers,  box of white peach mochi  and several little small sweets. The prices are so reasonable.  I can't believe being a born and raised city dweller I knew nothing about this gem. If you're here on holiday and Japanese is your thing don't miss this.
author: Claudia S.

description:
Best place to get authentic mochi! And it's very reasonably priced. I don't know how they do it but the mochi is still super soft and tasty. The packaging is good too. 

My favorite is the banana white chocolate mochi. Yum! Just picked up a box of strawberry and chocolate mochi. Can't wait to try it. 

I wish they gave samples so we could try before we buy, but I guess they would lose some money if they did that.
author: Cindy K.

description:
This place sells japanese sweets especially few chocolate candies, different flavors of mochi, castella (French influenced soft pound cakes), and cookies. They are made from a variety of sweet shops directly from Japan.

I tried the Harajuku Chocolat mochi - it's a mochi that has a chocolate infused mochi dusted with dutch cocoa powder. When I tasted it - it was sweet, but afterwards it had a slight sour taste which might the mochi(it was slightly fermented). I think these mochi are flavored with real ingredients to give a unique feel of your taste buds. The mochi doesn't stick to your teeth which is a good thing.

Although there a lot of varieties of candies, the prices range from $6 to 25 depending which variety you buy. Next time, I will buy the variety pack which has some tarts, mochi, chocolate cake balls, yuzu infused mochi, some french cookies (thin waferlike cookies with cream filling), and chocolate crunch cookies. This variety pack costs $15.95. A good value if you were to give someone who loves authentic Japanese sweets, or love mochi.  They also have some candy drops in different flavors like grape, orange, multi-flavored in small bags and in canisters.

This shop is great for gifts.
author: Jade M.

description:
A cute little sweets shop tucked away in the Kintetsu Mall, Nippon Ya carries a huge selection of flavored mochi, along with a smaller selection of things like cookies, all packaged in such a way that would suggest they're primarily designed to be souvenirs or gifts (not that one can't treat themselves every so often!). And affordable ones at that, with most boxes here running under $10 each.

As a note, the mochi they carry is of a more unique variety than I'm used to, with fillings such as a cream center surrounded by a layer of flavored red or white bean. Those who are looking for simpler and more traditional mochi may find themselves better off at the nearby Benkyodo Co, which makes excellent, traditional Japanese mochi.
author: Johnny W.

description: This place is absolutely adorable. They sell wide ranges of mochi and chocolate that are made in Japan. The cashier was very friendly and helpful. He offered samples of some of their mochi and chocolates. I really enjoyed it and bout some as gifts to bring back home from my trip.
author: Bei T.

description: Ah..glory, this place is a gem. So many goodies and the price is fair knowing it's coming from Japan. There's so many goodies and I must say, they all taste really good. My mom loves the stuff I buy her from this place and it reminds me of Mitsuwa. THis place is even better then the Sweet Things or whatever you call it on Market St. Def will come back!
author: Minerva L.

description: We went there to buy mochi several times. The mochi is OK but I'm very disappointed at the service today! The young lady in the store is not helpful but rude. We were just looking around to check out all these boxes because I know their products have short expiration date. Then we decided to buy a box of green-tea mochi. However, they didn't put the label-stand well. When the top box was taken, the label-stand started to fall down. We tried to put it back in place. The cashier ran to us and asked us not to take the boxes below the stand. Oh, gosh, we never did it!  Although we explained to her everything, she gave us a poker face which made us very uncomfortable! I will never go back to this store again and not recommend it to anyone else.
author: Xueying C.

description:
How can this place not have 5 stars??!

Everything is so elegantly packaged!  Go to http://www.sfjapantown.org/ and you can get a 10% off coupon. Expires on 12/31/2012. We bought over 10 boxes in total. Don't forget to get the green tea bags that are imported from Japan! The taste is so pure. So much better than the Americanized green tea......Highly recommend the choco mochi. Sooo good!!! The cashiers were very friendly and polite. They accept credit cards.
author: J J.

description:
I usually stop by this store, wistfully looking at the beautifully packaged and expensive mochi.  However, in either late April or in May, they were having extraordinary sales since they were getting rid of their old stock.  Prices were slashed as much as 60-75%!  I now have a huge pile of accumulated mochi wealth, thanks to Nippon Ya.  

If they still sell it, I highly recommend the peach mochi.  It comes in such a pretty box too.
author: Karen W.

description: I'm always interested in snacks from various countries so I'm always excited to see places are Nippon Ya.  On this trip I purchased a rice cracker, tofu with white chocolate cluster; it's very good.  I always bought cherry blossom tea.  Maybe I misunderstood the packing but there is no 'tea' just cherry blossom petals.  I read the ingredients just now and it contains alcohol.  I don't taste the alcohol and drink is light and pleasant.  It pairs well with the bread pudding dessert I'm having.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Mediocre at best. 

The people that praise Nippon Ya obviously haven't been to Benkyodo! 

I bought the $15 variety mochi pack. I'd give a solid 4-stars for the walnut-topped mochi and the black sesame seed covered mochi. However, I wasn't a fan of the pink (peach?) one and the mini mochi (on a stick) covered with brown powder.
author: Denise L.

description: Everytime I go to Japantown, this store is a must. Tiny walkthrough of a store but SO much selection of imported Japanese sweets! I truly feel like a kid in a candy store when I go here. Some items are a hit or miss and they do have samples for display and oftentimes have samples you can taste at the register. They also validate parking if you purchase $30 or more, obviously so easily doable by stocking up on the ever so delicious Harajuku mochi which is always a WIN!
author: Jenny Y.

description:
This place is absolutely a Mochi heaven. one of my favorite place to visit in japantown. love the packaging and details on their boxes. If you love mochi and other Japanese sweets.. You gotta check this place out. don't hesitate to ask questions to the ladies over there cos they will surely help you out... 

**cheaper too**
author: Cryszilla G.

description:
A great place to buy some omiyage (regional Japanese edible snacks, in nice pretty wrappers sold as gifts/ sourvenirs) in Japantown. It's not true that u can find most of these stuff at Nijiya, so don't bother. Each season usually brings a different supply of snacks. Love the many different types of mochi and jellies, but some items can be WAY too sweet. I wish they offered free samples so u could pick the ones u like best, instead of finding out the hard way that your choice wasn't that great.

Most everything is well made and carefully packaged, but these are not the best omiyage u can find. The regional fairs in the Mitsuwa market, or the Shirokiya store in Honolulu (they have free samples) have superior items - okay, yes that's too far away. It's just an example.

I would have given this place 4 stars in the past, but since Minamoto Kitchoan recently opened a store in downtown SF, it simply knocks this place out of the water. Service is pleasant.

They don't validate Japantown garage parking.
author: Luis C.

description: I absolutely LOVE this place. Whenever I visit sf, I always stop here to get mochi for my dad and I. Whoever works at the time is always nice and smiling. That's always pleasant! This recent time that I went, I guess I dropped my wallet in the store. I panicked and assumed it was gone forever. I received a call a few days later from my dad. He explained that our insurance called to tell us a man found my wallet. I called this man, and it was the owner of this place. He was nice enough to mail my wallet to me (I'm in Fresno)! Not only is the mochi delicious, the decor- cute, a really amazing person works here that did an amazing gesture. So thank you.
author: Shana O.

description:
Nice place to get nice packaged mochi from Japan, but it can not compare to getting fresh made ones down the block from here. I end up getting so much mochi for friends and family that I tend to get free bags of tea... or was it cause my friend knew the owners? **confused look** oh wells! free tea for me! 

If you are ever in the need of nice mochi gift to give to someone, this is the place to go!
author: Erica T.

description: real cool and nice shop but the mango eclair things taste kinda weird and u can taste more coffee than mango like wheres the mango mang lol and also the green tea cream mochi things dont taste like anything but the kit kats are good
author: Charles Y.

description: I bought the Memeta No Tofu Crunch (It's white chocolate).  It was so great.  It is crunchy like a white chocolate crunch bar.  It is the product in the cylindrical paper-like container with the really unique and funny characters on the sides and top.
author: B-Dubbs W.

description:
Gah, I like this place far too much. The presentation and artistry of all the desserts are so precious that I always (always) get suckered into buying something.  It's as if Nippon Ya draws out a compulsion that normally lies dormant in me. ("Don't like white chestnut mochi? I'll like it when it's shaped to look like a ducky! Too kawaii!!") 

Any gift-wrapped Nippon Ya box makes for a great present, in a very affordable price range. This is THE place to go when you need a present to impress (and travel well), but you don't want to blow your budget or lose your street cred as a "foodie."

The mochi here tastes fresh, supple and subtly sweet. The flavors are cross-cultural, featuring traditional fillings like adzuki, matcha, yuzu & kurogoma, and Americanized (but equally yummy) fillings, such as banana&white chocolate, strawberry&dark chocolate, etc. And since enjoying food is as much about sight as it is about taste, these treats will be sure to leave you satisfied.
author: Tianyi S.

description: When the boxes are unopened, then the mochi are great gifts.  I just bought 9 boxes and one of them was opened inside.  Unfortunately, I didn't find out until I got back home out of state.
author: Ryan Y.

description: So. Many. Mochi.  This place has so many different kinds of mochi, from sweet and fruity to the more traditional varieties.  Everything is organized and easy to find and everything is presented beautifully.  Displays are really helpful and there are samples too.  The only thing that I could say is that sometimes these displays are misleading.  I bought a box of Usagi Cream Daifuku in the cappucino flavor.  I thought that they would look just like in the display, all cute and bunny like.  What I got wasn't nearly as cute and appealing as the display led me to believe.  However, they were still insanely delicious, so there was that at least.
author: Christine W.

description: Stopped in here to grab some Mochi to take home with me. They have an amazing selection of sweets. I got a Harajuku Mochi strawberry filled chocolate version that was delicious. I only wish there were some combo packs so that I could have tried some other varieties. Only had so much room in the luggage, so I had to choose just one.
author: Cassandra F.

description:
I was staying in Japantown for the Cherry Blossom Festival.  It was an amazing event to experience.  While there I found this little Japanese sweets store.  They import yummy mochi, wafers, and so much more from Japan.  This place is a must if you are in the area.  They give great service, and can help you find something you will LOVE!  Sometimes they even have samples out!
I bought these freeze dried strawberries covered in white chocolate...OMG it was AMAZING!  I also got the chocolate strawberry mochi, the Harajuku ones...also AMAZING!  They have cute nicknacks too. :D
Overall, I LOVE this place.  The price is reasonable too.  I'm not from San Francisco, but if ever I go back, you know I will pay that place a visit!
author: Traci H.

description: I was craving for mochi and I heard good things about this place before my visit. This place has a good variety of mochi and other japanese snacks. They're great for souvenirs and gifts to take home and share with your family and friends. Most of the mochis don't need to be refrigerated so they don't spoil easily. They are also packaged in beautiful boxes.Try the Harajuku MOCHI chocolat. I think its the godiva version of mochis. What's good about is, you can see samples of mochis on what's inside each box on display. Don't hesitate to ask the cashier.  He was very nice and helpful. They also sell cute accessories such as keyholders. I bought one that looks like two kissing mochis ^___^ which are supposed to be for couples. You can give one to your bf and keep the other for yourself. It's cute!! This place is a must visit when in Japantown SF. Enjoy!!
author: Martha N.

description: Holy shit, stop what you're doing NOW and come here for some mochi!!! For just $10 you can get a whole box of soft, melt in your mouth, mochi imported from Japan. My friend had casually mentioned she woke up with a craving for Harajuku Mochi from J-Town, and randomly drove here at 10am to pick some up. I didn't understand why anyone would so such a thing at 10 in the morning until I tried these little pieces of effin heaven for myself. I immediately bought a box of chocolate Harajuku Mochi for myself and shared the joys with my bf. It is to die for, to fly for, to everything for.
author: Diane G.

description: Such a charming, cute little store in the Kintetsu Mall. Nippon Ya specializes in candies, cookies, teas, mochi, rice crackers, chocolates, and so much more from Japan. I've tried a large variety of the things sold here and I have to say that I haven't disliked anything. Most of the goods come wrapped in lovely paper and fancy boxes that make you appreciate the attention to detail and wish that sweets sold here looked just as pretty. There are descriptive signs detailing the sweet you're looking to buy, what it's made out of, and where it's come from, so don't worry if you can't read the Japanese packaging. There is also a small selection of cell phone charms and gifts for sale here as well. The prices for everything are a little high but the quality of the edibles are outstanding.
author: Angela M.

description:
holy sh*t. I hit the mochi jackpot. 

boxes and boxes of mochi (along with other treats) stacked and identified by a little placard of what region of Japan they are from. 

What I bought:
Harajuku Maccha & Sakura Chocolate Mochi
Sake flavored mochi (i know right??!)
Black Sesame mochi
Green Tea Daifuku
Strawberry Daifuku
Mango cake
Sampler set
Green Tea

All taste freakin bomb, I know this because I opened like ALL of the boxes on the car ride home. For as many pieces as you get in each box $8-10 isn't a bad price at all. SO good. I'm already trying to plan out what the hell I want to buy for my next trip. I saw a sign on the register that said they would validate parking for purchases of $30 or more. I didn't have my parking validated bc I was staying at Kabuki but just thought I would mention. 

I know not everyone is a fan of mochi so if you aren't fond of mushy or powdery textures don't expect these to be a 180 from that. Still, they are as flavorful as they can be :).
author: Abi U.

description:
Holy crap! I'm in mochi heaven!  I came here on my birthday in search of my birthday present to myself and mochi was all I wanted and mochi is what I got!  The tasty treats in here remind me of my trip to Japan as a child with all the beautifully wrapped boxes and delectable looking sweets. While these are not gourmet mochi, the sheer variety is staggering and the price more than affordable.

The service here was sort of ho-hum like the cashiers (there were three people behind the counter) really just wanted to go home.  They were definitely not interested in helping me on my evening mochi quest. Nor anywhere near as excited as I was, haha!

Good location though, with easy parking and easy access.
author: Marissa C.

description:
I don't really have a sweet tooth, but I do have a special place in my heart for mochi.  I could eat an entire box of that stuff and still want more!  

The best mochi I've ever had in San Francisco was from Benkyodo (they stuffed an entire strawberry into my mochi, what the heck?!  in a good way!).  But this place is pretty awesome too.

Why?

Well, here we gooooes!

+ The presentation.  Is stellar.  But that's what you expect Japanese people to do, right?  They've got pretty aesthetic stuff DOWN.
+ The boxes of mochi make for GREAT gifts.  Nicely packaged, a good amount of food, and really, who doesn't like mochi?
+ Good, extensive variety of typical mochi as well as unique ones like strawberry mochi stuffed with chocolate (whaaa?!).  It has something for everyone, I think.
+ It all tastes yummy! For reals, yo.
+ I was here last night, and the guy working the cash register was so friendly + boy was HELLA FINE.  That's like the best combination ever.  

Final word: The place is a tad bit expensive, but not ridiculously so.  But then again, most Japanese things are over-priced anyway, so if we look at it in context, then it's really not so bad.  I mean, eight bucks for a good-sized box of mochi is a deal, I think. 

Shout-out:  As mentioned above, Benkyodo is fantastic too.  They make their mochi fresh, and it's really delicious.
author: Vivian C.

description:
I was in J-Town and my partner in crime needed some candy treats for some friends. This store has assorted mochi with different fillings.  From green tea to fruit fillings, plus the ever popular chocolate ones. The boxes run between $8 to $10 a box and they are decorated very nicely This shop is small but it was neatly organized and you could find what you are looking for quickly.

They also have assorted candies, different gift baskets and stuff toys. Very Fun.
author: Jim D.

description:
This past Sunday found me, my sister, and my father looking for unique Japanese oriented gifts for the neighborhood families and some of my more eclectic friends who have absolutely everything.  

The location actually use to house the works of a local Japanese artist, so I was a little saddened to see him go.  His works of Sumi-e was pretty simple, meditating, and beautiful in the stead of typical Japanese artwork.  Now, that peaceful calm was replaced by something much more louder, happy, and colorful for capitalistic reasons.

I stopped by on my way to Kinokuniya to look for something cute, strange, and modern toy-like item for one of my friends in Sacramento.  I found one wall stacked with stuffed cotton renditions of parfaits and yogurt sundaes (imaginative, indeed) and a bunch of key chains with little characters and puffy bright goldfish.  Most of these were priced starting from $5.95 and up.  

Another wall carried several varieties of traditional Japanese snacks and confections to be consumed with green tea: 

Yokan:  Dense sugary squares or rectangular blocks made of boiled red bean paste, sugar, and agar agar (thickening agent).  Variations of the traditional red yokan runs the gamut, with chestnuts and full lima beans to strawberry - green tea - blueberry flavored yokan.
Mochi:  Tiny round mounds of sweetened pounded sticky rice molded around tiny pockets of sweetened red bean paste. 
Arare:  Baked or fried bits and shaped pieces of rice crackers, basted with a range of flavors: sweet soy sauce, sweet ginger powder, or salt
My papa purchased three boxes of the small Daifuku mochi for the neighbors while I contemplated the price tag of $10.00 for the Buru-Buru stuffed boars.  

In the end, I decided not to make the purchase and forged ahead to Kinokuniya for something with a little more substance: books!  Neat store for the passerby and curiously oriented, this is very reflective of Japanese retail Omiyage (gift) shops: cute, tiny, and lots of fun items.
author: Miika M.

description:
One of my favorite little shops!  Where else in SF can you find super-delicious, soft, chewy, strawberry mochi with creamy chocolate filling???  No where! That's where! Lot's of traditional Japanese treats with modern twists.   

There are lots of seasonal products.  Green tea and fruit treats in summer... Chestnut and persimmon treats in autumn and winter!  You can't beat this place for variety and reasonable prices.  Every box is between $7-10!
author: K M.

description:
Love this store! Much more affordable (though less fresh and fancy) than Minamoto Kitchoan, I inevitably find myself here every time I'm back in SF to buy some Japanese sweets to bring back home with me. These are the types of boxes you'll find at Japanese airports, tasty souvenirs to gift or enjoy yourself.

They don't always have my favorite (green tea mochi with red bean paste), but offer a variety of sweets to try out, mostly different types of mochi but also chocolates. If you never had mochi (glutinous rice cakes) before, you might be better served going to the nearby supermarket Nijiya and buying an individual piece since the boxes can be quite large. They are chewy, a different type of sweet, and taste great with tea.

In my last trip, they gave an extra box of goodies for liking their page on FB, so here's hoping they continue to run some extra deals for their fans!
author: natalie n.

description: Really good boxed mochi spot.  The prices were also very reasonable and the lady was very very helpful with answering all my questions.  This is a good spot if you need to bring gifts back home, however if you want the real mochi experience then make sure to get some fresh mochi at Benkyodo!
author: Sara H.

description: Yummy soft boxed mochi! The flavors are subtle and they are sweet but not where you can feel your teeth hurting with each bite.
author: Jenny S.

description:
A truly unique Japanese treats shop, shopping here makes me think of being in a Japanese department store's food department.  They carry fancy Japanese mochi, cakes, cookies, candy and tea in pretty containers, perfect for gift giving.  The mochi is the ultra fancy kind you don't see at Nijiya, Mitsuwa or other stores in the area.  These tasty goodies come from all over Japan, e.g., Hokkaido pudding cakes, castella cakes, crepe cookies, mochi filled with chocolate, rice cookies, mochi with crispy rice on the outside, red bean mochi galore.  

Everything is dainty and usually individually wrapped.  Most of the items have plastic model displays (so cute).  Some of the confections (like the banana kind) are labeled limited edition.  Packages start at $6 and up - most are under $30.
author: Lolia S.

description: Best place to get chocolate mochi. I  love their customer service. I get smiles and thank you everytime that I come in. Store is small, but you can find all the best mochi here. I also noticed that they do not sell the mochi that I like online, as long as this store continue to sell them, then I am more than happy to always buy them here. Of course, I would rather buy my mochi fresh at a local store anyways. I try to make a stop at Nippon Ya whenever I'm in Japantown.
author: J C.

description:
If you're looking for Tokyo Banana, you will be semi satisfied. There is an inferior version of the famed Tokyo Banana here, which is not nearly as good as the real thing in Tokyo. But, if you're just looking for something, ANYTHING, to taste like it, they've got it.

This store is actually great, reminds me a lot of the mochi/sweets boxed sets that are sold everywhere in Japan (subway stations, convenience stores, etc). There is plenty of daifuku, mochi, crispy treats, cell phone fobs, etc.

So far we've had the fake Tokyo Banana (dry and less banana creme filling than the original), chocolate banana daifuku, and azuki green bean mochi. Not bad!
author: Katherine P.

description:
F*** Ya!
Not cheap.  But such great mochi - soft, supple, delicious.
Will try other reviewer's suggestion for Benkyodo which is the only reason I didn't give this place 5 stars (will edit stars if that place doesn't compare).
So far, the strawberry chocolate has been the best mochi.  And the vanilla/white chocolate cookie is SO good.
author: HQ G.

description: This is a very place to come come for unique Japanese sweets. As part of my Valentine's Day gift I bought a box of 16 mochi with strawberry flavored filling.  The price ($9,99, I think) wasn't bad either compared to items you get at, say, Godiva's. The feedback I got is that it's delicious and probably healthier than regular chocolate.
author: H K.

description: Cute little place. Definitely coming back if I have to get gifts that isn't just your average box of chocolates. They have a sample for you to try at the counter. It was chocolate w/ chocolate filling; it was delicious!  I wish they had some more samples so I can taste them, since they are a little pricey and there are so many diff flavors! The plum hard candy that they sell in the little bags are also yummy too.
author: Allyson L.

description:
Cute little store full of sweet Japanese yummies. All beautifully presented and boxed, down to each individual little cookie or mochi, so I wince at the prospect of needlessly expanding the landfill, but it all looks so kawaii I can't resist. 

Some of the items have plastic model displays so you can get an idea of what to expect inside the mysterious boxes, but many more just have text desciptions that can make it hard to commit (no buying by the piece here). The boxes don't come cheap either. 

They also sell some cute little trinkets like "cakes" that are actually ingeniously folded towels, keychains, and small stuffed animals, including something that was cute I knew I just had to buy it for my sister on Christmas...

*RING RING*
Sister: Hello?
CY: Hey, what color do you like? 
Sister: Depends on what it is.
CY: Err... (standing in store, on cellphone, looking at the said object in complete confusion).. it's... a... puffy.. lucky... fishie... thingie...
Sister: A WHAT???
CY: A puffy lucky fishie thingie. They have red, yellow, green...
Sister: Orange?
CY: No orange.
Sister: Well... I guess green then...
CY: You sure? It's a BRIGHT green..
Sister: Well is it a bright LIGHT green?
CY: Yeah I guess you could call it that. 
Sister: I guess that color's ok then. But .... what the heck is a puffy lucky fishie thingie???
CY: TOO LATE! You dibbed it, you got it. See you on Christmas!
*click*

LATER ON CHRISTMAS WEEK:

CY: Here you go...(hands over present)
Sister: Aw it's soooo cute!!
CY: SEE!!!! HOW WOULD YOU HAVE DESCRIBED IT????
Sister: Puffy... lucky... fishie... thingie.
author: ChiYan T.

description: If you take the time to ferret out this little shop in the far corner of the Japantown Mall, you won't regret it! At first I thought I'd gone to the wrong place, not realizing the store front actually faces the mall court, as opposed to the street.  Then, I had to wind my way past all manner of cafes, gift shops and trinket stands.  But I was on a mission. Once I found nippon-ya, I immediately knew I had hit the mochi motherlode! This little shop is the real deal--you'll be transported straight to Tokyo (or any other reasonably sized Japanese city.)  And the choices:  chocolate, summer orange, matcha, chocolate strawberry...for starters. Beautiful, neatly wrapped boxes stacked sky high. Oh, and don't forget the perfect accompaniment: tea! A robust assortment of Japanese teas, tea canisters, tea pots and a guide of the different varieties. I left with a bag full of goodies, and will definitely return for more. Next time, perhaps a gift for someone ELSE.
author: Alison M.

description: I stop by this shop while I was in japan town and saw the mini mochi with all type of different flavors.  I decided to try their harajuku mochi chocolat banana, strawberry and green tea flavors.  I love each one of them.  The mochi was soft and tasty. The filling was also tasty and not too sweet.
author: Dante D.

description:
For a candy store with so many positive reviews, I was really underwhelmed.  First of all, the mochi is EXPENSIVE here, seriously.  The "daifuku" is really just strawberry flavored mochi filled with nutella.  The filling totally ruins the flavor and the texture of the mochi, not like real strawberry daifuku with real strawberries and anko on the inside.  

The green tea mochi was disappointing, and tasted a little like latex.  Not to mention, the cashier was kinda rude and made me feel like a dumb weeaboo just for being there.  I don't think I'll be back.
author: Jessica N.

description:
I took my brother here when he visited knowing he would love it.

He did.

He (and I) love this cute little shop.  Its packed full of Japanese sweets, packaged beautifully and all stocked and arranged wonderfully.  It's a small store, but because it's so well organized it's not crowded or overwhelming.  Its very clean and well lit, everything just pops out because of the light and all the colors.

It is certainly more pricey than getting candy at Ichiban.  But you don't come here to buy Hi-Chews.  You come here to buy boxed mochi and other Japanese delights.  Try it Mikey, you'll like it.
author: Jen K.

description:
Bean paste cakes = happiness!

Mochi = WTF?

Warning:
Try mochi before you buy them to see what you think, as they are very weird and gummy if you haven't had one before.  I got some as gifts for people when I got home, and they were less than pleased, but everybody loved the bean paste cakes.  

This store is seriously fun though, and getting mochi without taking my Utah family into account was my own damn fault, so they still get 5 stars :)
author: Sarah C.

description:
I was always walking by this place and thinking, " What the FXXX, Who is buying the old Japo sweets things. I go Benkyo-Do in stead to get fresh made sweets. I never come here for sure."

Benkyo-Do closes 5 pm sharp!

My taxing woman, she is an old Japanese lady, went to Japan few weeks ago. When she was there, she fell and hit her hip born hard, didn't break it but she was hurt badly.
She is just came back in here and doing my tax so I decided to bring something for Omi-mai= visit, inquire her health.
So, I went to Benkyo-Do 1st but it was too late, 10 minuts after 5!

Benkyo-Do is great because fresh made and pick whatever I want and they have a little pink paper box and wrapping shit.
Benkyo-Do is So Parfect the situation that I was in.

I love Benkyo-Do from bottom of my heart but it was closed.

I was sucked!
Flower? Flower dies and gets dirty and she isn't my GF.
I didn't know what to do.
So, I just walk down into the J-town building and I stopped right front of this place again.
And I said, " Shit."
But I walked in.
There are so many good Japanese sweet stuff.
I found a nice box of Maccha Yohkan set. $14.
I think I know this thing must be about 6 bucks in Japan, but looks nice enough to be 14 just because you don't see this kind in here.
Cute design too.
Yohkan= bean jelly,
but,
Yokan= hunch,
Yakan= kettle or late night,

And, they have a special wrapping cloth for $1.50!
( if you bring something and just wrapping will be $2.50)
THAT"S RIGHT.
WRAPPING JAPANESE WAY!
This was FXXXin' cool. When I give the Yokan box with the cute wrapping to the taxing woman, she said to me, " Oh, You just got back from Japan too?"

Wrapping is a big deal in Japan.
Have you been any department store and purchase in Japan?
Especially basement, is always food department, they wrap so fast and so precise! I always feel guilty to open it.

Anyway, I Thank Nippon-Ya.
She loved it.
You made my day.

P.S., there is a cute Asian girl who took a Wrapping class!
Julie K. from NY said, " YES!  once I took a class for it in Korea!  Wrapping is a big deal in Korea, too!"

Wrapping class? Should I?

Btw, if you are a guy who has a Japo girl friend, get a good Yohkan. I think Yohkan is a KILLER for Japo ladies. You might get lucky.
"Hana yori Dango!"
author: Nobu K.

description:
I have a buddy who is an Asian Fetishist weirdly enough. The problem is that he is also uncomfortable around women. It's seriously painful watching the whole ordeal. For some odd reason, he thought it would help him integrate into their society if he held an Asian Snack Party. I'm not sure if I see the reasoning here, but I guess talking about snacks is better than talking about recent tax laws when you are trying to score a date. 

Now, me being the good friend that I am decided to fight my original notion which was to not attend this event and to run screaming/laughing in the opposite direction. No,  I'm gonna pitch in and help out. At the very least I get to see some more uncomfortable small talk right?? 

I don't have the first clue what one would bring to an Asian Snack Party... My idea of snacks is beer and popcorn. I don't think they have corn or corn products throughout Asia so what's a guy to do??? JAPANTOWN that's what!!! I pop into Nippon-Ya and it is like a snack heaven. Sweets. Savories. They have it all. Thankfully they also have an English translation sign by every product because even if there is English on the original packaging it doesn't make sense. For instance, I left with a bag of Beer Mame and on the bag it reads, "Oh! 21 DREAM." I also left with some Wasabi Mame and Dried Filefish?!?!?! 

The shop itself is modern, overly bright, and welcoming. The staff were all incredibly helpful and didn't make fun of my towering height or round eyes!!!
author: Bucky K.

description:
It's a great place to get Japanese style sweets.  There are lots of chocolates, assorted mochi (non-ice cream), and more to choose from.
It's a great gift, and the prices are fair.

My personal problem with it is---I can never finish a box by myself.  Many boxes usually come with 12-15 count of mochi.  The mochi aren't particular big--but usually satisfiying with 1 or 2 pieces.

*TIP - Be sure to keep it in a zip-loc or something to keep the freshness.  Mochi aren't meant to be stored for more than maybe 2-weeks. (from personal experience).

Definitely worth checking out if you like sweets, asian sweets, or just wanna try something new~!
author: Jerry C.

description: It's no Benkyodo, but there is a huge variety of mochi and Japanese snacks for super cheap prices.  Where else can you get 12 pieces of daifuku for only $8?  The boxes are also colorful and pretty--perfect for omiyage.  Nevertheless, I wouldn't come here if I wanted to snack on some mochi myself.  The stuff here isn't fresh, it's packaged and the mochi is hardened and tastes more bland as a result.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
One of the must-stops in j-town.  When they first opened, I thought it was kinda cute because it totally reminded me of the gift shops in the Japan airport.  But what keeps me returning to the store is the great selection of authentic Japanese confections.

My favorite is the strawberry mochi with chocolate filling.  Seems like the secret on that is out though, because it kept selling out.  Good thing the store has gotten smart and now keeps it well stocked.  The green tea mochi with chocolate filling is just as great.  Also love the garlic shrimp chips (made with real garlic and shrimp!).  What else.  The shrimp rice crackers.  The persimmon jellies when it was persimmon season.  The cherry blossom mochi during cherry blossom season.  The mochi with white peach white bean filling during peach season ... you get the picture.

And the non-food stuff is cute too.  Like the little plates and kiddie spoon/fork sets.  Too bad I don't have kids to buy them for though.  And the kimono silk bangles and hair sticks would be very pretty, if only I had bigger hands and longer hair.

All that adds up to four stars and the fifth star is for the service.  The tall Japanese-looking girl always gives me great suggestions on what's good (like what I might find too sweet or too bean-y).  And she's never been wrong.  And oh, one time I saw her demonstrate to some lady how the kimono hair sticks work.  How neat!  Awesome overall!
author: spiff e.

description:
I don't like chocolate very much. Not big on american sweets.. But I love me some Japanese confectionery treats. OH yes I do. 

Came here just to look for this particular wafer treat that I really love - fukuwatashi senbei. They didn't have it... But they did have a lot of other great things, all in the beautiful packaging that makes it such a great gift to give. 

They also had "kotobukiame konpeitou". Which is the really colorful traditional rock (sugar) candy!!!! I had way too much of that when I was in Osaka. But I still love it.
author: Jen D.

description:
Purchased some gifts from here. While the packaging is nice, the sweets are merely ok. Not worth it for the price in my book. That being said, there are other high end sweets that have moved into town, so this place will have some competition (sweet!).

Also, they have started selling random nick nacks and cell phone straps.

I heard rumors some time ago that they use to have massive sales when they switched from one season's products to another. I've been here a good amount of times, but never came across any sales. 50-70% off sales.. Myth? Legend? 

Surely someone must know.
author: Tyrone B.

description:
Update: I heard my leggy Asian beaut' has left for bigger and better which is a tremendous loss to this store, but alas another package of mochi will have to suffice to supress my borderline depression

----
All the awesome mochi goodness and neat Japanese trinkets are secondary to the leggy Asian beauty of a store manager Kristina who always offers service with a smile. Hubba Hubba!
author: Andrew I.

description:
I really wish I liked this place more...

One of my favorite things to do in Japan was to stop off at a shop at the train station wherever I might be visiting from Kyushu to Hokkaido to check out the local specialties. I would inevitably bring lots of stuff (omiyagei) back for friends and business associates not just a courtesy but an obligation.

Nippon Ya has some of this but its weighed too heavily on the side of distinct and unusual. Just give me more of the traditional regional and tried and true okashi and mochi.
