author: David P.

description:
THIS PLACE IS EVIL! 
I saw Genevieve's review of this place and when she mentioned mochi I had to pay this place a visit.

From across the mall through the crowd I spotted a wall with rows and rows of mochi! Mango...chocolate...green tea...strawberry! 3 boxes for $8! To my left twinkling in the sunlight where boxes of strawberry daifuku for $8! There's a basket of chocolate, strawberry and yogurt filled marshmallows. Were these sale prices I saw? There's a display case of freeze dried bananas and strawberries covered in chocolate. Not only do they look good but they taste good too!

They also have cute stuffed animals, key chains and toys. Packaging is super cute so I can come here to buy a last minute present. A little pricey but some of these things you can't find anywhere else in the city so pony up here or you can drop cash on a plane ticket to tokyo.
author: Lola L.

description:
Yummy yummy yummy I got mochi in my tummy...

I used to try and make it a point to stop in to this adorable mochi store every time I was in J-town, but lately I've been trying instead to make it a point NOT to stop in... 'cause I know I will probably go home and devour a gift-sized box of these sweet things in an evening. My favorite is the strawberry mochi with chocolate filling. It's like eating frosting surrounded by strawberry pillows of joy.

Nippon Ya sells a wide variety of Japanese mochi confections, ranging from traditional to modern flavors. The products are a little pricey, but are great for gifts. Has anyone ever said "WOW!" after receiving yet another janky box of See's candy for the holidays? As many of the reviews point out, the packaging is super cute and unique, so it definitely stands out as something special.
author: Stephanie P.

description: When Japanese people go on a trip, they return with gifts or "omiyage" for friends, family members, neighbors, or co-workers.  Nippon-Ya has various omiyage from different regions of Japan.  For example, Osaka is known for Takoyaki (octopus puffs), so they have Takoyaki snacks in a nicely wrapped box.  Nippon-Ya is such a unique shop it's worth checking out.  They only have non-perishable food items, so they don't have mochi or dorayaki that would go bad in a week.
author: トモ T.

description:
I passed by here this past Saturday morning. Quite an impressive store, unlike the rest of the shops in the same building. A shame they were not going to be open until 45 minutes later and I could not stick around.. 

Word has it this place sells Tokyo Banana! 

In case you were wondering, no, that is not a devious refence to a  3rd leg, man's best friend, or a "small Japanese weenie" (according to Nobu K).

Tokyo Banana is a pastry/snack that if I remember correctly looks like a swiss roll cake, but inside has a wicked banana cream filling that tastes like the real banana flavor. I could not find this at any Nijiya, Mitsuwa supermarkets in the Bay Area, and last time I had it, a friend gave us some when she was in Tokyo, and I was seriously hooked.
Not all junk food tastes good, but I make an exception for this.

http://www.tokyobanana.jp
author: Ken K.

description:
Since it's Chinese new year, this self proclaimed princes was craving for some red bean moon cake.

I for one refused to go to Chinatown because I don't have the patience to look for parking or deal with tourists. And my lazy ass, don't fel like driving to Clement St. so Japan town here I come.

Lo and behold, Mr & I found Nippon Ya, the closest red bean I found was the mochi red bean. The box I grabbed have a beautiful wrapping and it cost me $15.95.

Got home, unwrapped the box, found 20 itsy bitsy pieces of mochi red bean that I devoured within 10 mins. Granted it's yummy but my craving wasn't pacify. And I guess the price is intended for the wrapping.

Now I'm off to 99 Ranch where I can find red bean moon cake, half the price what I paid for in this place. And they don't validate for parking.
author: jubi l.

description: It's a bit pricey, but the presentation is nice, pretty packages.  It's more of a gift place.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Not that this changes my opinion of the shop or the products (as I'll still be buying them), but just as an alert to others: most of the products contain packets of descciant to ensure freshness. I'm assuming it's not toxic, but it is a little disconcerting to get to the bottom of a tin of candy and find a little packet of this stuff labeled "Do not eat."
author: Andrea W.

description:
I came here for the first time and wandered the mochi aisles in despair, knowing that this store was not for me.

And then, I saw it. A concept so alien, it had to be an experiment gone terribly wrong ...

... or terribly right.

Shiso-ame -- SHISO HARD CANDY!!!

$3 for a bag of shiso-leaf goodness.

Just for this, I give Nippon-ya Eleventeen stars.

I also recommend the maccha (green tea) and shouga (ginger) ames.
author: Pat T.

description:
all i gotsta say is this:

GREEN TEA MOCHI WITH CHOCOLATE CREAM FILLING.

mind you, this is chocolate cream that tastes like nutella. 
somebody hand me some matcha and i'll be all set.

other favorites include the decadent chestnut cream- and black sesame-filled mochi. not only are the flavors immensely satisfying (not too sweet), but you get to treat your mouth to the pleasurable pillowy, soft, chewy textures.
author: jennifer y.

description: Great shop for gifts like mochi manju and more. They have lots of flavors! Even had a dried fish section!
author: Emme K.

description: Do not buy the rare cheesecake (gelatin cheesescake), everything else is great!
author: Tiff T.

description:
This place fills my need when I'm heading out San Francisco and coming home/visiting a friend. Instant omiyage right here in this shop. And they've got a pretty envious position in the middle of the Kinokuniya mall too.

I've been lucky to have a few pieces of their candy here as well and everything is pretty good. As far as preserved mochi goes anyway. If you want fresher stuff, check out Nijiya or Benkyodo. But this place is an instant gift for friends if you have nothing else in mind.
author: Roland C.

description: Has very unique and yummy candies. I also love that they have matcha (powdered green tea). I like to use it to make my own matcha lattes at home. I also really love the yubari melon corn chocolate. It's very cool that there's a place like this to get authentic Japanese candy imported directly from Japan.
author: Sami Y.

description:
The majority of sweets this place sells are, like most typical modern Japanese packaged sweets, filled with artificial flavors, artificial colors, preservatives, and tons of palm oil, one of the most unhealthy edible oils out there.

And okay.  Let's say you don't mind eating all that.  Fine.  But you should know that unless you specifically want the pretty packaging Nipponya features so that you have some nice-looking omiyage to give out, you can get a lot of the same treats for much cheaper at Nijiya Market.  Better yet, if you can get to it while it's open, Benkyodo makes various sweet treats FRESH.

I have found a few good items here that I would go back for, and when I'm traveling long distances to see people, I buy gifts here because it's not as practical to transport fresh sweets from Benkyodo.  So yes, do give this shop a look-see, but know that it WILL be overpriced for what you get and that you should research some other shops in the area before opening your wallet.  The generous reviews here are just astounding to me.

P.S. Try the shiso-flavored hard candy.  It's the only place in J-town where I can find such a thing; otherwise I would never pay $3 for a handful of rock candy.
author: James L.

description: japantown center inside...bright and packed mochi shop...boxed and pretty...strawberry to chocolate and more...a request for mochi...osaka kuri mochi $seven.seventy-five...a chestnut mochi box....quite soft chew and sweet center mochi...finding mochi heaven...in prepackaged, pretty boxed and stacked mochi...
author: Hen A.

description:
I LOVE this place!!! They have SO many interesting snacks you won't find anywhere else.  I don't come here too often due to the fact the prices can be rather expensive (that's why I gave it 4 stars) but when I go there my wallet gets pretty light afterwards. =P  So far the things I've tried has been delicious except for  the mango mochi which I didn't like.  The mochi was soft but it didn't taste like mango to me.  Chocolate mochi was good but can be too sweet.  And their chocolate covered dried strawberries are great.

Crackers I've tried were also great!  Especially this one box of crackers I bought last week that was meant to be given to my boyfriend's family but since he had so many other stuff to carry on the plane he left this one which I'm glad he did because it sure is delicious!!  The crackers are round and had 6 flavors (almond, coconut, green beans, etc) that tasted just like they're supposed to (~$15).  

All their snacks are nicely wrapped and even if they're not wrapped just the box itself looks nice.  Great place to buy for family or friends as a gift if they like exotic japanese snacks.  Plus they have other cute non-edible gifts on the left side of the store you can browse through.  I signed up on their email list more than a month ago and haven't received anything yet but according to a guy working there, he said last email they gave 50% off on the new arrivals for people.  Too bad I missed it but looking forward to an email soon for discounts.
author: sidney c.

description: This is my favorite place to buy unique Japanese mochi and snacks. I love that everything is packaged so nicely and I can always find something new here.  All their mochi is super soft and delicious. My favorites are the chocolate strawberry mochi and the summer orange mochi. Definitely my go to place to buy yummy gifts for family and friends.
author: Hannah C.

description: This small little shop is very colorful and cute. I loved their mochi and other sweet delicacies packaging they have. They also have cute and interesting souvenirs/gifts, which I couldn't help myself and bought a bunch back home. If this shop got me to buy a number of items, I wonder what happens when I really go visit Japan...might need to go there with an empty suitcase and just stock up on things.
author: Sandy C.

description:
Yummy, yummy yummy yummy - such a cool store for authentic japanese candies/confections.

I'm not Japanese, so this was my first time trying things that I never heard of - I think I'm addicted now.

Also, all of the stores in the Peace Plaza are such cool spot to find cheap, but cool things - a fun way to spend a couple hours and then have lunch at one of the many great restaurants.
author: Kristen W.

description:
This place is expensive!!! You pretty much pay for the cuteness and packaging. The stuff I bought tasted ok. Nothing to brag about or even buy a second time around. 

I will give them one more chance. Reading other reviews for this place, the mochi sounds good and I will have to try it.

Great little shop in Japan town. They specialize in candies, mochi, tea, a whole bunch of japanese knick knacks. They are constantly getting new stuff in every week. Be sure to check this place out when visiting Japan town.
author: David W.

description: Randomly found this little gem when were walking around. I was so pleased since I love anything mochi! I bought a box of mango cream mochi they are supper yummy! I tried a free sample of some chocolate mochi something or other and that was just heavenly. I'm going back tomorrow to get some more since there isn't a place like this back home.
author: Suzy R.

description:
Nippon Ya is bar-none my one stop store for candy gifts. The small (yet roomy!) shop is stocked to the brink with absolutely wonderful varieties of Japanese confectioneries--so much so it's almost mind blowing. It's amazing to see how well decorated the boxes are, with some even wrapped in cloth. If you are looking for that delicious, beautiful gift for your friend or family, look no further than Nippon Ya.

Be sure to pick up the strawberry mochi with chocolate. Fantastically delicious to say the least.
author: Steven S.

description:
Clean and cheerful store hosting many Japanese sweets, especially for mochi.

My favorite mochi is the new summer orange flavor.  It's individually wrapped so I can keep it in my purse for a treat when needed.  

The green tea chocolate mochi Bf picked might be good too but they were not individually wrapped.  In a smaller size and you have to finish them quickly.  Maybe good for party dessert. 

Their packaging is nice too and great for gift.
author: Ile F.

description: Mochi!! They have a good selection of mochi and dango for such a small shop.  Definitely worth a visit if you have a sweet tooth for more traditional japanese confections.
author: Jackie C.

description: Let's say you are going to someone's house for dinner and since you have some manners you don't want to come empty handed. You could be dull bring all the same old boring stand by items or you could bring weird candy that no one that hasn't been to Japan has ever seen. The prices aren't too bad and they gift wrap.
author: Manny F.

description: When I go to Japan, I come back to the US, visit this store, buy gifts for people who don't know better and tell them I got it in Japan.
author: Wakako U.

description: I can tell you that I was very sadly never ever able to buy a single box from here whenever I visit japantown, but I can say that this shop is somewhat very small and the confections here are very tasty. From traditional desserts to unique ones like chocolate. prices are a bit expensive depending which one of the many boxes you buy. it's the perfect gift for when you are meeting someone for the first time or as a thank you.
author: Jessica T.

description:
i heart this place.. everytime i go to sf i come here...

i think the decorations are so adorable.... the actual mochis... are not so great tho... hahah 

but its cute to give out to your friends...~ so deff go here... if you want to make some gal happpy~


and its pretty cheap.. wen they have those 20-40% off sales~
author: Eunji y.

description: I came in here a few times only to buy those cute fish key chains but I know that they also sell other things. This place is really small but really cute. Filled with packs of cookies, pastries, and mochi balls but way way to expensive for me. Even the fish key chain was already $7. Maybe i should come here to get my mom or bf's mom pastries for Mothers Day, which is coming up pretty soon! =D
author: Tracy A.

description: daifuku heaven. this place has a lot of gift-type japanese snacks. It's small and right next to the andersen bakery in the Kintetsu mall. I came here to buy 5 boxes of the ichigo no choco daifuku once for gifts. o.o
author: Ryan Y.

description: I came here to buy my friend a little something and I got her strawberry mochi with dark chocolate hazelnut filling. It was yummy! It was pretty worth it $8 for a box of mochi. All of the goodies here are packaged so nicely.  They have all of the most popular things in this one stand if you are not sure what you really want, I believe that is very helpful.
author: Janet Z.

description:
This store is VERY colorful with all the brightly packaged yummies along the walls and on tables.  I've never bought anything from here before but I decided to try once box of SOMETHING yesterday!  I went in not really knowing what exactly the shop sells so I was reading every little description placard like a noob and blocking everyones way.  I wish there was more "walkspace" in there and a way to sample some them.  Everything sounded really tasty but most of them were $8 a box so I decided to just get the chocolate mochi because it was labeled as a "staff favorite pick" or something like that.  The young man that works there is friendly and inviting too.  

The chocolate mochi I got was OK.  It was just regular mochi rolled in cocoa powder.  I should've read the description more carefully because I thought it was chocolate FILLED mochi!  They're kind of addicting though.
author: Dong Q.

description: Mochi Mochi, yelper-san.  If you find the gift wrapped, ambiguously labeled boxes perplexing, or you just want to try this mysterious Japanese confection you can't go wrong with Strawberry mochi.
author: Marjorie B.

description: This place is stocked with shelves of mochi wrapped up so elegantly!!!  Makes a great gift for any occassion.
author: Mick S.

description: One of the fun little shops to wander into while in Jtown, Nippon Ya has mochi boxes after mochi boxes to choose from.  Around the end of May, beginning of June, they have a 75-90% off sale, which brings the prices down to anywhere from $1.75-$4 a box.  Great deal!  Last time, my friend was visiting from LA and we happened to be in Jtown that weekend.  When she saw the 75% off signs, she just about flipped out.  She bought no less than 25 boxes of strawberry chocolate-filled mochi to give as gifts, and then made her bf the official mochi carrier.  I bought a box too and I can now say that strawberry chocolate-filled mochi are my favorite kind...velvety chocolate wrapped in lightly flavored sweet strawberry mochi...you just gotta try it.  Words won't do justice.
author: Swirls L.

description: Whoa! Mochi galore and other sweet treats placed in well iluminated shelves. I recently just bought some freeze dried strawberries covered in white chocolate --- the flavor = Strawberries that will make you pucker that have a consistency of a Lucky Charm's Marshmallow all covered in milky White Chocolate goodness.
author: Charm N.

description: Very attractive and such exquisite packaging of mochi and Japanese snacks and desserts. Tried this one box of chestnut mochi which was beautifully packaged and was almost reluctant to open up the box but I had to savor the content....anyhow, the mochi was just ok. I've yet to return and maybe try the other flavors that Yelpers recommended. Pricey but I guess that's the price to pay for packaging and nice gift boxes.
author: Yan M.

description:
if you're looking for japanese goodies that you cant find in other asian stores, come here! you can find arare, mochi, daifuku, and a whole bunch of other goodies! 

the food here is on the pricey side. i bought these crepe rolls and mango daifuku. for both items i spent around $16. expensive as hell but very good! they also make good gifts!
author: B B.

description: A whole package of daifuku is too tempting while at the same time the same couple of flavors in a pack of 12 could be monotonous.  My boyfriend didn't want to buy anything because he read the preservatives in the ingredient lists.  The selection of boxes are overwhelming but you can't really choose a variety because everything comes in a set.  There is only one attendant to process your purchases, who sits in wait for you to ask questions.  This is like a cheaper version of Minamoto Kitchoan without the funky pricing system.
author: Ai M.

description: I haven't had a thorough look inside this place, for I've only skimmed the inside once or twice and looked from the outside many, many times. It looks interesting though. But it would be a lot more helpful if I knew what half the stuff was.
author: Elaine H.

description:
I normally don't get too detailed on my favorite food item or whatever the place I am commenting on. A taste of Japan rite at your doorstep. OK, well they try to put out much as possible for the square foot in the store but it comes down to this. There are several local favorates in the Japantown area that offer "Japanese snacks". Sometimes you can't help of being a little overwhelmed or picky.  Different strokes for differnt folks.
Being a small shop on the side just before you hit Benihana rite in front of that dim walkway path into the restaurant area,
located in the mall. A variety of Japanese snacks such as mochi and candy..Yummy! Mainly snack items that are wrapped in paper for your convenience. You can practically find something as a gift item. Packaged very well in contemporary but tasteful design it is easy to see how they run out of certain favorite's. 
Plush dolls and key chains are also available. Moderate pricing for your budget. It's a cute shop. Open late like after 11AM. 
the cashier was friendly and helpful. Even nice enough to give you a coupon. How about that?
author: Smooth R.

description: As far as the variety of items beign sold is concerned, I can't compare this business to other places that might sell similar items because I am only familiar with this place, so I do not know if it is "As good as it gets," that is, five stars.  However, they do have what strikes me as a very large selection of mochi and other food items. The packaging is beautiful, and the displays are nice.  Open display boxes for many of the items allow you to see see what is inside. In the past, I have bought a Baumkuchen cake for my brother and sent it to him in another state; he said the taste was just "OK."  I have bought other sweets here that were very tasty.  And the mochi items taste very good.  Prices are not cheap for some of the items, but again, I cannot compare prices to other places. Today, we bought four different items for $36, and there was no sales tax (yeah!).  I guess some kinds of food items not consumed on the business's premises are not taxed.
author: M T.

description: I used to always come here because the chick behind the counter was nice.  Their chocolate mochis are delicious -- when they're ever in stock.  Sometimes I would get a couple boxes so I can give them out to friends as gifts, but I end up eating them myself.  So delicious.  It's a cute place.
author: Michael B.

description: This place is extremely expensive but it was all about presentation of how stuff looked in here. I was skeptical so I went in thinking "what the hell am i gonna buy?" I saw some kind of sweet squishy cake with lychee in it and since it was $15, so what the hell right? the lady workn there gift wrapped it and all. man..i felt guilty, the wrapping looked so perty and shiny since it was the foiley kind. lol it tasted alright so I guess I can't complain too much.
author: Jason C. J.

description: Fun food gift items. Wild things like chocolate filed mochi, strawberry and lima bean mochi, wild omiyage for a Sunday when Benkyodo is closed. Check it out. Each item is super packed with individual plastic wrapping.
author: miriam b.

description: zomg! i remember going here after the JLPT from year 2006 or 2007! :D anyways, i remember that i got some different kinds of mochi... they have tons of selection of mochi, that you wouldnt regret getting them! yay
author: Marc K.

description:
thank you nippon ya for reuniting me and chocolate filled green tea mochi ( =  and for that...  i am happily giving you 5 stars ( =

this place has now been added to my "must-go-to" list when i am visiting the bf in the bay area~  why? so far this is the only place where i can get my hands on the chocolate filled green tea mochi that are oh so yummy~!  the first time i had them was when brother brought some back from japan and ever since then i've been trying to find them in the u.s. with no luck.  until this past weekend when i googled it again and found the nippon ya link.  ( =  i tried the chocolate filled strawberry mochi, although it was pretty good...  i still like version with the green tea better.  i was too happy to see the green tea mochi with chocolate that i didn't bother buying other things, but most likely i'll do more damage the next time i'm there.   now...  if only they have a nippon ya in socal then i will be even happier  ( =  or if anyone knows where i can get these chocolate filled mochi in the l.a. area...  please let me know ( =
author: karina o.

description: THIS PLACE IS GREAT! EVERY MOCHI FLAVOR YOU CAN FIND! EVEN CHOCOLATE!!! I love the little fish toys they sell. I hang one in my car =] and on my keys for work =]. The price is fair considering it is in Japan Town. I love the chocolate in green tea mochi. It's delicious!
author: Miss D.

description: i remember when this store first opened i was like OOO!!!! looks good! *walked in, looked at prices, ran* although the prices are a bit up there its worth it! and also they have cute cellphone accessories! i bought mine from there! super kawaii! but i still prefer the vanilla ice cream mochi. at some local grocery stores near you!
author: Amalia D.

description: cool and cute mochi confections wrapped up in pretty packaging.  they have different flavored ones with interesting fillings.  a great idea for a gift to bring to someone's house for their dinner party or something.
author: charlotte s.

description: Not only do they have cool snacks from Japan but they also started carrying Japanese Hello Kitty stuff! I like how their display is really clean, like supermarkets in Japan. A definite stop when going to J-town!
author: M F.
